par.text: Pure iron is a silvery-white metal of moderate hardness and high ductility. It exhibits strong ferromagnetic properties, meaning it has the ability to become magnetised in a magnetic field. Iron maintains this property up to a temperature of 770

C, referred to as the Curie point. Pure iron is resistant to air and moisture. Iron containing impurities, however, quickly becomes covered in rust – a mixture of hydrated oxides. Very fine iron powder can ignite spontaneously in air. Iron was known in ancient times; evidence has been found that it was used in Egypt as early as 4000 years ago.
